thread.title: Tourists robbed, US woman raped on Colombian coast | Daily Mail Online
thread.title_full: Tourists robbed, US woman raped on Colombian coast | Daily Mail Online

author: Associated Press
title: Tourists robbed, US woman raped on Colombian coast | Daily Mail Online
text: Just after midnight on Friday, masked intruders invaded a popular resort at Playa Rosita, near Taganga, Colombia - robbing a group of tourists at gunpoint and allegedly sexually assaulting an American woman. The victim of the reported assault was a 42-year-old Massachusetts woman. One of the victims told Colombian digital news site Seguimiento.co that he and another man were tied up and held at gunpoint while a woman from Massachusetts was raped on the terrace of a model house. Just after midnight on Friday, masked intruders invaded a popular resort at Playa Rosita, near Taganga, Colombia They bound and gagged nearly a dozen tourists and allegedly assaulted a 42-year-old Massachusetts woman One of the victims tells Colombian digital news site Seguimiento.co that he and another man were tied up and held at gunpoint while a woman from Massachusetts was raped Mayor Rafael Martinez of Santa Marta has offered a 20 million peso reward for any information on those responsible He said there were at least four men demanding that the tourists tell him where the owner of the lodging site was, and that they had a Venezuelan accent. The tourists reportedly include travelers from Spain, France and Belgium. The thieves took around five million Colombian pesos, close to $1,734, and cell phones and personal items from the tourists. Mayor Rafael Martinez of Santa Marta has offered a 20 million peso reward (nearly $6,928) for any information leading to the prosecution of the suspects. He asked of the Taganga community on Twitter to 'denounce these acts' and to help ensure that those responsible 'do not go unpunished'. The Mayor also reportedly plans to beef up security in the area and conduct searches on the surrounding businesses to ensure that they are operating legally. This included the hotels and hostels popular among tourists.
